did.unittitle: Bernhard Knollenberg collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Correspondence, diaries, manuscripts of writings, narratives, biographical sketches, documents, reports, addresses, deeds, tax receipts, printed material, and other papers, relating to early American colonial settlement, the American Revolution, settlement of the West, slavery, the Civil War, Spanish-American War, women's suffrage, and various political questions. Includes circa 100 letters (1838-1855) to Alvah Hunt, of Greene, Chenango Co, N.Y, describing current political issues, especially Whig politics, from Millard Fillmore, Hamilton Fish, Horace Greeley, Washington Hunt, William H. Seward, and Thurlow Weed; 171 letters written by Homer Sackett Curtiss to members of his family during his Civil War service in the 2nd Connecticut Volunteer Regiment, Heavy Artillery; papers of George Panton, loyalist, of New York, containing letters from Daniel Batwell, Thomas Bradbury Chandler, other loyalist Anglican ministers who escaped to England during the Revolution, and others interested in the Church of England in America; 35 letters and documents (1779-1804) by and relating to Nathanael Greene; correspondence, deeds, and tax receipts, relating to Joel Barlow and the Ohio Company; 2 volumes of letters and papers by Fran√ßois Alexandre-Frederick La Rochefoucauld Liancourt; correspondence and writings of Seth Reynolds; and diaries of Alfred Brammer, English workman.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Bernhard Knollenberg Collection (MS 26). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Correspondence to George Panton is available on microfilm (circa 125 frames on 1 reel, 35mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library, at cost. Order no. HM199

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series: I. Correspondence, 1560, 1622-1942. II. General File, 1747-1827, 1858-1868, 1901-1940.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Bernhard Knollenberg Collection comprises original and copied manuscripts of American historical interest which were collected by the former Yale University Librarian in connection with his historical studies and presented to the Yale University Library in 31 accessions since 1939. Covering the entire span of American history, the collection is of major importance for the Colonial, Early National and Ante-Bellum Periods and is frequently consulted by the leading scholars of these periods. The typed and photostatic copies of manuscripts were obtained from many libraries and historical societies and from private collections.

Bernhard Knollenberg (b. 1892) was University Librarian from 1938 to 1945 and Lecturer on the Law of Taxation during the academic year 1941-1942. A student of law and history, he held the following government posts: senior deputy administrator, Lend Lease Administration, 1943-1944; division deputy, Office of Strategic Services, 1944-1945; and, United States Commissioner for the North-West Atlantic Fisheries, 1950-1958. Mr. Knollenberg was the recipient of five academic degrees: B.A. Earlham, 1912; M.A. Harvard, 1914; LL.B. Harvard, 1916; Honorary M.A. Yale, 1939; and LL.D. Earlham, 1944. The following books by Mr. Knollenberg as well as a number of journal articles were based in whole or in part on the manuscripts in the collection: Washington and the Revolution: A Reappraisal , 1940; Whitewater Valley , 1946; Samuel Ward , 1952; Origin of the American Revolution , 1960; and George Washington: The Virginia Period , 1964.

The manuscripts and copies are arranged in chronological order in 1220 folders (15 document boxes) and are individually foldered and described. Most of the items are individually catalogued in the Union and Departmental Manuscript Catalogues. The collection was established with the gift of the Alvah Hunt Papers in 1939. Over 100 letters written during the period 1838-1855 to Alvah Hunt of Greene, Chenango County, New York describe the political issues of the time, especially Whig politics. The principal correspondents include Hamilton Fish, Horace Greeley, William H. Seward, and Thurlow Weed. Other groups of papers of interest are listed below:
1. The Leffingwell Collection of manuscripts at the New Haven Colony Historical Society. Gift, 1942. Photostats.

2. The George Panton Papers which were presented to the Reverend Dr. Chorley by the Bishop and the Synod of the Diocese of Aberdeen and Orkney in 1934 and given to the Library in 1940. The letters are from Anglican ministers who were Loyalists and who escaped to England during the Revolution. A few are from men who were never in America, but were deeply interested in the Church of England in America. The two principal correspondents are Daniel Batwell and Thomas Bradbury Chandler. Chandler graduated from Yale in 1745 (see Dexter's Yale Biographies and Annals , 1701-1745 ), moved to England in 1775 and returned to America in 1785. He was an important figure in the Anglican Church in America. George Panton, according to Sabine's American Loyalists , was in New York in 1783 and was one of the 55 Loyalists who petitioned for lands in Nova Scotia at that time.

3. Homer Sackett Curtiss Papers, consisting of 171 letters written to members of the Curtiss Family during his Civil War service in the 2nd Connecticut Volunteer Regiment, Heavy Artillery. Gift, 1939.
4. Nathanel Greene Papers, including 35 original letters and documents by and relating to General Greene, 1779-1804. Gifts, 1943, 1944.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials related to Aaron Burr, B. Silliman, Theodore Woolsey, and E. G. Salisbury were transferred to the the Burr Family Papers (MS 303), Silliman Family Papers (MS 450), Woolsey Family Papers (MS 562), and Salisbury Family Papers (MS 429) respectively. Additionally, some materials were transferred to folio-sized folders for preservation. The transfers resulted in gaps in the folder sequence.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Yale University librarian (1938-1945); administrator in the Lend Lease Administration (1943-1944), Office of Strategic Services (1944-1945); U.S. Commissioner for the North-West Atlantic Fisheries (1950-1958).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

did.unittitle: Correspondence (Chronological)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains letters, manuscripts, documents, reports, printed material and photostatic copies of original material. The folders are arranged chronologically, with undated material arranged alphabetically by author's name at the end of the series.

Topics covered include early colonial settlement, the American Revolution, slavery, The Ohio Company, the Civil War, the Spanish-American War, woman suffrage, and various political questions in the individual states and the nation as a whole. Many important historical names are found, including George Washington, John Adams, John Quincy Adams, Benedict Arnold, Paul Revere, Marquis de Lafayette, Horatio Gates, John Hancock, John Jay, Philip Schuyler, Thomas Paine, Anthony Wayne, Eli Whitney, Henry Knox, Nathanel Greene, John C. Fremont, John C. Calhoun, Daniel Webster, Benjamin Harrison, Robert Morris, Dorothea Dix, Susan B. Anthony, John Gibson Lockhart, John Singer Sargent, Edward Everett, Lewis Cass, William Sherman, E.C. Agassiz, James C. Dana, Augustus Saint-Gaudens, Theodore Roosevelt, Franklin Roosevelt, Jay Norwood Darling, and Charles Beard.

A large number of letters are from Homer Sackett Curtiss, a Civil War soldier, to his family. Another group of letters are to Alvah Hunt, New York political figure, from William Seward, Governor Hamilton Fish, Thurlow Weed, Daniel Webster, Millard Fillmore, and Washington Hunt. A third voluminous mass of the series consists of material such as deeds, tax receipts, and correspondence pertaining to Joel Barlow and his dealings with the Ohio Company.
Various narrative accounts and diaries are found in the series. These cover settlement of the West and biographical sketches of War heroes and frontiersmen.
See Also: Series II for writings which complement correspondence found in Series I.

did.unittitle: ALS, Maximilian (King of Bohemia); "To Whom It May Concern" - grant passage to carrier ? Vienna
ALS, Leopold V, Archduke of Austria (1586-1683), to The Duke of Tuscany; requesting that Angelo Vettori be given a governor's job by the Duke
A Copy of an Act of Parliament during the first year of the reign of James I concerning the poor; copied by Ralph Hopton

ALS, Emperor Ferdinand III to the Mayor and Council of the town of Fridtberg answering their plea remove their contributions to his army. The Emperor urges them to continue contributing the necessary support
Copy of document attesting that all undivided land after the second division in the town of Haverhill shall remain in the common possession of all towns people. Copy by Mitchel Sewall Clev
Testament concerning a piece of land and what it contained; Thomas Danforth, Recorder. Language may bar co-mixture of Low German and English
A funeral sermon preached in Madrid at the interment of Richard Hanshaw, His Majesty's ambassador there by Dr. Bagshaw
Deed of Hezekiah Williss of Hartford, Connecticut; deeded land to John Camp of Hartford in return for the indenture of the said Camp
ALS, Will Trumbull to Richard Bulstrode from Paris; concerns the conditions of Dutch in Paris and talk of the treaty between Spain and France
Proclamation from the proprietors of East New Jersey to their settlers; that Lewis Morris has been given a grant of land to use to obtain naval stores for 6 pounds rent per year
ALS, Admiral Sir George Byng (1663-1733) sent from Port Mahon to Mr. Craggs; tells of reading for sea
ALS, Robert Hunter to Lewis Morris; thanks Morris for papers sent and asks him to fill in for him in a business deal
ALS, Rev. John Davenport (Stamford, Conn.) to Rev. Stephen Williams, (Springfield); tells of supplies going up river from Davenport to Williams
ALS, Louis XV (France) to Monsieur Pucelli; requests absence from People's Assembly
ALS, Jonathan Belcher (Governor of Mass.), to Rev. Nathaniel Chauncy (of Durham, Conn.); describes goods and a bill sent by Belcher to Chauncy. Boston
ALS, Lord Barrington to Lord Auson; recommending Captains Craven and Barker to Lord Auson's protection

ALS, Earl of Sandwich to (?); urging that Mr. Robbins, who had written an excellent treatise on gunnery, be allowed to go to the seige of Bergen op Zoom and subsequent seiges to put theory into practice

ALS, Franz III, Duke of Lorraine, to Archbishop of Trier; message of the death of the Archbishop's father carried by the Marquis de Lambertye. Letter in German with typed transcription and translation
ALS, Indenture certificate between John D. Osborn and various citizens of Albany
Rent of land by James Rickets (Prince William County, Virginia) to George Mason (Charles County, Maryland) for 20 pounds
ALS, Daniel Dulany to Charles Carrole; asking Carrole to survey the south side of Dulany's land

ADS, Frederick the Great of Prussia, appointing Johann Christian Friedel "Adjunctus Fisc.", describing the duties, responsibilities, limits, and pay of said office. In German with transcription and translation
ALS, Barrington to (?); asking for a transfer of Barrington's brother from the ship Bellona to another vessel
ALS, Jacob Wendell (Oliver Wendell Holmes' grandfather) to Capt. Michael Butler; requesting that Butler pay the bills due to Jacob Wendall, Jr
ADS, Robert Morris to Nicholas Scull (Surveyor General of Penn.), authorizing the survey of 25 acres in Berkshire County for Charles Korn

ALS, C.V. Livingston to Robert Morris (Lieutenant Governor and C. in C. of Penn.); concerning the arrival of Col. Dunbar and two regiments of troops and the necessity of procuring supplies and transportation of the troops
ALS, Robert Hunter Morris to (?); concerns the disbanding of provincial troops and the state of affairs in Penn. Mention of Franklin, recto p. 2
AL, [Robert H. Morris?] to William Allen; concerning the way to stop the meeting and protests of the people of Lanchester County
ALS, (?) to Miss Lake; chronicle describing America
ALS, Duke of Newcastle to (?); concerning the sale of property. Newcastle felt that he had been cheated in sale and asked his friend to bring the matter to the attorney general
ALS, Duke of Halifax to (?); concerning a Mr. Lowry and a dispute over land that he bought or claimed
ALS, Rev. Soloman Williams to Rev. Eliphalet Williams of Hartford with a cure recipe for Eliphalet's sore leg; also has family news
ALS, Horatio Sharpe, Governor of Maryland, to the Commissioners of paper currency calling for an accounting of loans due
ALS, H. Moore to CO; discusses the removal of his household from Jamaica to London for health reasons
Account page from a doctor's book, showing the debit of Enoch Parker
ALS, Hardwicke to (?); discussing the islands and lands that England owns because of the Definitive Treaty
Cash record of William Dabney Ambler
AL, From the King (George III) concerning the duties of a Mr.Ellis on the King's business
List of debits and credits signed by Benedict Arnold
ALS, George Grenville to Fessey; discussing the purchase of an estate in Westcoate Field
List of Commissioners and Officers of His Majesty's customs
AL, (John Hancock) to Richard Lawler thanking him for his help and asking Lawler to hold prosecution of Mather and Parsons Company
Bill signed by Benedict Arnold against Richard Ewin
Negotiable note from Dudley Woodbridge to Matthew Barns on Mr. Joseph Bently
List of regimental officers of Massachusetts photostatic copy
ADS, Roger Sherman; list of debts and assets signed by Benedict Arnold [photostat]
ALD William Lee to Robert Caster
List of debits and credit signed by Benedict Arnold
ALS, Dr. J. MacKnight to Rev. George Panton; requesting that Panton look after some household goods until MacKnight gets resettled. Also photostat of same
ALS, Dr. J. MacKnight to Rev. George Panton; speaks of furniture moved and being shipped as well as his plans for the future. With photostatic copy
ALS, Dr. J. MacKnight to George Panton; discussing the possibility of sending sermon materials via manservant to MacKnight. With photostatic copy
ALS, J. MacKnight to George Panton; asking him to send a mare and a saddle horse from Jedburgh to Temple on Dec. 22. With photostat
Petition from George Panton to J. MacKnight asking for a change of school location in Jedburgh and requesting that the school be made a boarding school. With photostat
Copy of the Boston Gazette and Country Journal
Notice from James Duane, attorney to Cortlandt Skinner, attorney for the defendant, that trial will be Sept. 6 in the town of Perth Amboy
Legal document signed by John Dickson concerning the estate of Robert Hunter Morris, one of the proprietors of East New Jersey, and the settlement of claims due that property
ALS, R. Trailly to George Panton; at the University of Edinburgh - promising Panton a letter of recommendation to the Bishop of London so that Panton could change his job situation. With photostat

ALS, Bishop James of Down to David Hume; concerning the ordination of George Panton as a priest in Scotland. Down asks for permission to be obtained from the Bishop of London, who is the proper Bishop of Scotland, to perform this consecration. With photostat
ALS, Bishop James of Down to George Sandy; concerning ordination of George Panton as priest if Panton can get dismissory letter from the Bishop of London. With photostat
ALS, Professor William Trail to George Panton; stating that he thought the Bishop of London would give the dismissory letter. With Photostat
ALS, Bishop James of Down to David Hume; stating that the dismissory letter had arrived and requesting George Panton to be present with testimonials on February 20. With Photostat
ALS, R. Traills to George Panton concerning letter to be delivered by Panton to the Bishop of Down and expressing regrets that Panton is leaving. With Photostat
Cover of the ordination papers of George Panton signed by Bishop of Down, David Hume, D. Traill, Mr. Sandy, and Professor William Trail. With Photostat

ALS, J. MacKnight to George Panton mentioning the offer of the Bishop of Down to give Panton a place in Ireland and asking Panton to consider if the Bishop's offer and possible friendship might not come in handy in America. With Photostat
Receipt for diploma of Master of Arts granted to George Panton. With Photostat
ALS, J. MacKnight to George Panton concerning the collection of debts owed to Panton. With Photostat
ALS, J. MacKnight to George Panton indicating that Panton trained under MacKnight and that MacKnight has sent him a general letter of recommendation. With Photostat
Deed to a plot of ground in Duchess County, Mass. William Brown to David Doty
Instructions to Thomas Hutchinson upon his appointment as Governor of Massachusetts. Photostat
Instructions governing the laws of trade and navigation given to Thomas Hutchinson, Governor of Mass. Photostatic Copy
ADS, Deed for land, David Van Horne, Hugh Wallace
Benedict Arnold's accounts of sales at the Bay of Honduras
Invitation to dinner, Mr. Riddocks to George Panton. With Photostat.
Contract between P. Smith and Benedict Arnold for the delivery of Red Stone to Arnold for 20 shillings per square foot. Photostat copy of original
ALS, Rev. D. Williams to Stephen Williams explaining why he cannot lend his horse to his father
ALS, Isaac Low to Jellis Fonda acknowledging the receipt of furs, asking Fonda to send some Pearl Ash to sell
ALS, George washington to (?), relating to the settlement of Col. Thomas Codvill's estate. Photostat copy of the original
Contract between Benedict Arnold and P. Hezechiah Bassit Photostat copy of original. for construction of a house
ALS, John Thomas to Joseph Trumbull, letter of introduction of Mr. Cushman. Photostat copy of original
ALS, Richard Varick to Robert Yates asks for an answer in a legal case which concerns a Mr. Scott
ALS, Henry Quincy to son, discusses the son's sale of a vessel he had built, speaks of his own discredit
ALS, J. MacKnight to George Panton, congratulating him on becoming established. Speaks of educating his own sons and putting them into business. With photostat copy
ALS Vam White to Messers. G. J. Dickerson asking to extend his bill of credit 100 pounds until his vessels arrive
Copy of AL to Committee of Correspondence in Boston from secretary James Nudien of Newburyport stating their actions in regard to the landing of East India tea
ALS, J. B. Chandler to George Panton concerning the affairs of Panton's missionary post in Trenton, N. J. with photostat copy
ALS, Sir Frederick Haldiman, governor of Canada, to Rev. William Smith thanking him for a pamphlet and information
ALS, LLL to Rebecca Woolsey expressing his love and devotion and a promise to see her and marry her in the spring
ALS, Adam Drummond (British statesman) to John Watts talk of the rebellion of Boston, use of threat of force, but not the use of force
ALS, Governor Sharpe of Maryland to John Ridout, asking Ridout to act as agent in a business deal in England
ALS, Adam Drummond, (British statesman) to John Watts speaks of family and trade

ALS, Turgot, Anne Robert Francis, (Finance minister under Louis XVI)-1727-1781- to Monsieur La Mothe, indicating that he had received his suggestions for agrarian reform and would use them at the proper time
Account pages for Vessels Polly and Peggy kept by Benedict Arnold
ALS, L. Lloyd to Rebecca Woolsey, Lloyd tells his feelings of the impending revolution. Letter carries instructions to burn it after reading
Deed from John Quintin to Joseph Shippen for a tract of land in Northumberland County, Penn
ALS John Stevens to Col. Benedict Arnold at Fort Ticonderoga, contains intelligence of operations in New York State. Photostat copy of original
Document signed by President John Hancock to George Washington, appointing him Commander-in-Chief of the United Colonies Army. Photostat copy of original
Order from Walter Spooner to Col. Benedict Arnold for him to deliver the livestock in his possession to Col. James Easton. Photostat copy of the original
Bostwick, Elisha, 1748-1834, photostat copy of his service with the Connecticut infantry

ALS, Col. B. Harrison to Gen. George Washington; tells Washington what is happening in Philadelphia, recommends certain people to the General, indicates that now colonial currency will be printed soon. Copy of original
ALS, Horatio Gates to printer. Copy
AL, Horatio Gates to Col. Baldwin; concerning the care of the poor sent from Boston to Chelsea
ALS, Richard Peters to George Panton; urging Panton to attend the annual convention despite the unrest in the nation. With Photostat
ALS, Col. James Warren, 1726-1808, to [?]; on arriving safely at Philadelphia. Mentions Adams, Cabot, Cushing and Hancock. Photostat of Original
ALS, Thomas Lynch, 1794-1779 to [?]; discussion of the affairs in the Carolinas, lack of supplies, and the impending journey of a convention delegate to New England. Photostat of Original

ALS, Nathanael Greene to Governor Ward; seeks to correct a misunderstanding that the poor were not those who were making money on the war, but rather the merchants and wealthy planters. The colonies must work together in harmony. The need to retain the arms of those whose enlistment is up, but despite all colonial troops are not well armed. Photostat of Original

ALS, Philip Schuyler to George Washington; telling of the death of Montgomery, the wounds of Arnold, and the dangerous situation of the troops and pro-Colonial Cause Canadians. He pleads for reinforcements

ALS, Horatio Gates to [?]; George Washington tells of the capture and fortification of Dorchester Heights and American cannon fire into Boston and the lack of return fire from the British. Photostatic Copy

TLS, John Adams to Gen. Horatio Gates; Adams urges the driving of the British from Boston and when that is done, for Gates to block the harbor. Adams feels that we have waged only half a war. Speaks of the Parliament's Act of Independency that sunders America from the Empire
ALS, Nathaniel Shaw to Christopher Leffingwell urging the forwarding of cannon as soon as possible. Washington's letter of same date included. Photostat of Original
ALS, George Washington to Esek Hopkins; warning him of an impending British blockade of New London and asking that cannon and stores be sent to George Washington. Photostat of original
ALS, Horatio Gates to John Adams; liberty and safety can only be secured with independence; a generally harsh letter to Adams in reply to his letter of 23 Mar 1776
ALS, John Adams to Horatio Gates; a reply to Gates letter of 23 April in attempt to soothe the General and enable the General to understand the politician's position. Photostat of Original

ALS, Horatio Gates to John Adams; met Col. Clinton, speaks of Sullivan's move to Albany and from there with 10,000 men to Quebec; praise of Arnold, wants to stay in command in Boston, but will go where the Congress wants him to. Photostat of Original
AL, H.K. to John Adams; discussing the most valuable texts on the art of warfare that should be made available and read by American officers. Photostat
TLS, Nathanael Greene to [?]; urges recruitment of new troops before the British increase their forces

ALS, Dr. T.B. Chandler to George Panton; tells Panton that 40 pounds in relief funds for loyal American clergy is on its way to him, but more funds are difficult to come by. With Photostat of Original

ALS, John Adams to Horatio Gates notifying Gates that he has been placed in command of Canadian forces and calling to his attention and favor an Adjutant named Rice already in Canada. Photostat copy of original
Typed copy of a letter from Horatio Gates to John Adams, stating that the army in Canada is in peril and that the army is split into many segments
Memorial of the judge advocates concerning rules and articles for the government on the subject of court martials in the service
Estate left by A. Hummell to Benedict Arnold; Value 112 pounds
Typed copy of a letter John Adams to Mr. Chase, speaks of the Declaration of Independence, defense measures for New York

ALS, Horatio Gates to John Hancock) writes of the retreat to Ticonderoga; the epidemic of smallpox; the attempt to check the British advance with a hastily prepared naval force. Photostat copy of the original

Typed copy of a letter from Horatio Gates to John Adams, complains of lack of power; the poor state of the army; the unfair report of Samuel Chase to congress; joy over Independence Declaration; need for instructions to the paymaster
Typed copy of a letter from John Adams to Horatio Gates, excuse for Samuel Chasers report; need to stamp out smallpox; need for regular returns and accounts every month
TL by Horatio Gates to John Adams; the appointment of Mr. Rice as major; asks favor for Lieut. Col. Baldwin, an engineer; expresses hope to hold enemy if the British can be kept from Staten Island
ALS Jonathan Trumbull, governor of Connecticut, to Governor Cooke of New York, discussing plans for the defense of New York City and eastern Long Island
ALS, Jonathan Trumbull to William Williams; discusses the condition of the American army and the fleet and the controversy about Gen. Schuyler, whose character he warmly defends
ALS, Elisha Buss to John Buss; family letter from a brother at home to one in the army
ALS, Horatio Gates to [?]; relates the preparation for going into winter quarters and the expiration date of some of the state militia; asks for replacements. Photostat of Original
ALS, Gen. (Mad) Anthony Wayne to Horatio Gates; tells the conditions of Fort Ticonderoga-many sick, enlistments up, poor food, hands tied by headquarters. Photostat of Original
LS, George Washington to [?]; giving permission to go to Philadelphia, but wishing the addressee would go to Bristol instead. Photostat of original
Virginia Declaration of Rights. Photostatic copy
ALS, Governor Schuyler (New York) to Gen. Washington; success in New Jersey campaign; Albany. Photostat
LS, Jonathan Trumbull to Jabor Huntington (written in hand of William Williams), Sheriff, signer of Declaration of Independence. London
ALS, William Duer and Jonathan Tompkins to Major General Wooster; disposition of troops. Photostat
ALS, Castriss, Marshall of France, to M. DeCerdaine (French); regarding property and demands concerning it. Paris
ALS, Roger Sherman to William March; regarding various requisitions for men and supplies for the army. Photostatic copy

ALS, John Adams to Nathanael Greene; stating that we should match our men, man-for-man, with the British; officers are not leading the men correctly, abandon the defensive plan - letter never sent - too impolite
ALS, Richard Peters (War Office) to (?) urging the removal of stores and arms to a safe place, perhaps near Baltimore, stating the War Office. would pay freight

ALS, Horatio Gates of John Hancock, need for troops and supplies to hold Ticonderoga, newly recruited regiments are understrength; conference with Governor Trumbull to obtain more troops and supplies; apathy seems to reign

ALS, General William Heath to General George Washington, introduction of General Conway from France; information on the state of France in records the American cause; indicates that some gunsmiths might be persuaded to come to America. Photostat copy of original
AL, John Adams to Nathaniel Greene, pages 3, 4, 5 only; describes, by analogy, the art of intrigue and its use in the art of war. Photostat copy of the original

ALS, Philip Schuyler to Philip Livingston, James Duane and William Duer, army has run down during his absence; provisions are wanting; inadvisable to maintain long lines at Ticonderoga. Photostat copy of original
ALS, General Arthur St. Clair to John Hancock, explains dire straits at Ticonderoga; fear of British attack. Photostat copy of original
ALS, Israel Putnam to (2), explains all is in readiness to leave via ship from Peekskill as soon as sufficient vessels arrive. Photostat copy of original
ALS, Joseph York (Lord Dover) to Sir William Hamilton a letter of introduction of one Mr. Tenhove, the nephew of Grostier Tagel, a friend of Yorks's

Extract of a letter, George Washington to the Council of Safety, Washington fails to understand why General St. Clair evacuated Fort Ticonderoga; hopes to protect Albany; complains militia disappear as quickly as they come. Photostat copy of original
Petition to Brigadier General Conway from the Field Officer of his Brigade concerning the appointment of Rev. Dr. William Rogers as chaplain. Photostat copy of original

ALS, General Philip Schuyler to George Washington, militia enlistments up; explanation why Ticonderoga evacuated; only a few continental troops; fear of enemy attack; need for reenforcements or that section of the country will be lost

ALS, Joseph Wright to Governor Thomas Johnson of Maryland, contains the statement of a case of an American, captured by the British, let go on parole being re-enlisted and going to fight again without having been exchanged
ALS, General Arthur St.Clair to Horatio Gates, states that he couldn't hold Ticonderoga with 2,000 men, especially since 1/4 of them would be up in enlistment soon. Photostat copy of the original
Role of Captain John Bayley's Company, Joseph Marshe's Regiment. 36 men listed
Photostat of the Connecticut Courant for the week of Sept. 1, 1777
ALS, General J. Conway to (?), requests command of a bridgade of light infantry, citing his experience in command under fire as credentials of his bravery. Photostat copy of original
ALS, General Conway to (?.), the use of engineers to lay out campsites and fortification before the troops arrive so they can begin; at once is very successful. Photostat copy of original

ALS, Horatio Gates to John Hancock, the victory at Bennington has helped build militia strength, need of money by the commissary; need for blank commission papers to commission officers. Photostat copy of original
ALS, General Philip Schuyler to Colonel Parrick, expressing hope that the arrival of Gates will compel General Burgoyne, to leave Saratoga. Photostat copy of the original
ALS, General Philip Schuyler to (?), the British have withdrawn, none of the buildings at Saratoga were burned. Photostat copy of the original
ALS, Israel Putnam to John Hancock, problems of delaying the British if they land on Long Island or New Jersey. Photostat copy
ALS, by General Conway to (?), complains of being overlooked, pushes his own ability and demands the rank of major general. Photostat copy
ALS, Benedict Arnold to Horatio Gates, complains of mistreatment, of only being a cypher in the army, will stay despite Gate's jealousy, urges the general to action. Photostat copy
ALS, Horatio Gates to John Hancock, information that Burgoyne has only 15 days' provisions, Gates will hold off enemy's assault and cut off retreat. Photostat copy
ALS, Horatio Gates to George Washington, enemy still holding same camp and have fortified it, the British have to make a move within two weeks; need for munition supply. Photostat copy
ALS, Richard Peters to General Anthony Wayne, the avarice of the people hurts the revolution, we should pursue an offensive conduct of the war. Photostat copy
ALS, Israel Putnam to Horatio Gates, situation unchanged along the North River. Putnam has about 2,500 continental and militial troops but mostly militia. Photostat of original
ALS, Horatio Gates to John Hancock, letter with the convention of Saratoga and the surrender of Burgoyne. Photostat copy
ALS, General Conway to John Hancock, tells that he sent an honest report and just criticism of the army; that he still deserves a higher rank. Photostat copy

ALS, Horatio Gates to (General Burgoyne) relates the treatment of wounded British Officers; asks for an exchange of Col. Ethan Allen, tells Burgoyne to stop burning houses as he leaves toward Canada. Photograph of original
ALS, Benjamin Austin to Benjamin Franklin, serving as a letter of introduction of his son and asking Franklin to look out for the boy in Paris. Photograph of Original
ALS, John Langdon to Benjamin Franklin, copy of articles of capitulation of Burgoyne, describes the battle of Saratoga. Photograph of Original
AL, Colonel Hamilton and moves on the east side of the Hudson River mentioned in this letter segment. Photostatic Copy

ALS, General Conway to (George Washington), explains that he did not wrongly criticize the army or Gates, that opinion should be exchanged between general officers, that he intends to write an account of his experiences in America, but will tell only the truth. Photostat of Original
ALS, General Conway to Horatio Gates, telling Gates that he has resigned because of treatment by Congress. Photostat of Original
ALS, General Conway to Horatio Gates, congratulates Gates on his new appointment, promises to send his observations on how the Army could be improved, and a plan for the Army. Photstat of Original
ALS, General Burgoyne to Horatio Gates, complains of the quartering of officers, particularly Generals, thanks Gates for the good he has done. Photograph of Original
ALS, General Conway to Charles Carroll (delegate to Congress from Maryland, signer of Declaration of Independence). Reasons why he resigned. Photostat of Original

ALS, James Lovell to [General Gage]; tells of the poor state of the armed services, the need for men, the defeat of Burgoyne and the appearance of a European war keeps the American cause looking respectable. Photostat of original

TLS, Lafayette to Major Bouchet telling Bouchet not to promise for France things that France cannot fulfill; also to take care on his journey back to France; expresses concern for the plight of Gen. Conway

ALS, Rev. T.B. Chandler to Rev. George Panton; speaks of how things are in London, indicates that the Missionary Society will continue to support Panton, even though he was driven out of his mission. With Photostatic Copy
TL, [?] to Lafayette; urges the retaining of Gen. Conway and Lafayette's help in the matter
Extract from the minutes of the Board of War, acting on Gen. Conway's resignation, creating the post of Inspector General to be filled, as defined by Conway. Photostat of Original
ALS, John Buss to Stephen Buss; describes the conditions at Valley Forge, the erection of wooden huts and the scarcity of food

ALS, General Thomas Conway to [Horatio Gates]; Conway feels discriminated against, unjustly accused of conspiring against Washington. Wishes he did not have the post of Inspector General, but rather ambassador or envoy to France. Photograph of Orig

ALS, General Lafayette to George Washington; urges the creation of a company manned by Frenchmen, under French Officers in Morgan's corp. Speaks of the Conway business. Urges that the office of quarter master general be established. Photostat
Petition sent to John Hancock from the Brigadier General at Valley Forge, denouncing the undue promotion of General Conway. Photostatic Copy

ALS, Tench Tilghman to [General Washington]; conditions at Valley Forge are good; one British raid; fear of a Junto involving Gage and Conway and others; the real reason of Bourgoyne's surrender. Photostat of original
ALS, Eph. Blayne to Col. Harrison; report of an overheard conversation indicating that Conway had made a fool of the Americans. Photostatic Copy
ALS, Gen. Lafayette to [George Washington]; speaks of Gen. Conway and how he has made the American Congress look foolish. Photostat of Original
ALS, Horatio Gates to Marquis de Lafayette; the appointment of Lafayette to command an expedition against Montreal. Photostat of original
ALS, Horatio Gates to Brigadier General Stark; Lafayette first in command, Conway second in command; Stark to cooperate with them. Photostat
ALS, Horatio Gates to Colonel John Gruton; the C.O. at Albany tells in detail the proposed plan for invading Canada and directing his cooperation. Photostat of Original
ALS, Robert Morris to Richard Peters; introduces Dr. Shippen, relates that General Washington is being blackened unjustly; glad that Peters is staying clear of party politics. Photostatic Copy
TLS, John Adams to Benjamin Rush, stating that Continental officers don't lack skill or bravery, but are wanting in diligence and patience. Typed Copy
TLS, William Duer to Francis Lightfoot Lee, Duer had been accused by Lafayette of being a Tory, Duer feels dissolution of the Army is imminent. Copy
TLS, Lund Washington to George Washington, tells of talking with Lee and that Congress has no plot planned against the Commander-in-Chief. States that flour should sell well. Typed photostatic copy

ALS, T.P. to Colonel R.H. Harrison, need of supplies for the next campaign, an exchange of prisoners is about to take place. Why let healthy British troops go back to fight when all the Americans held prisoner are weak and sick. Photostatic Copy of Original

ALS, Benjamin Rush to (George Washington?), talks of Dr. Shippen and his neglect of duty while Chief Physician and the action taken by Rush as new Chief Physician to correct them. Photostat of Original
Receipt of money from William Paterson, total of twenty-two pounds. Signed Charles Pettit
ALS, Thomas Conway to (Horatio Gates), wants to know why he should not be in the main action instead of a holding one. Photostat of Original

ALS, George Lux to Major General Green, wishes Green luck in his new appointment, talks of the decline in Continental money, Arnold and Lincoln to serve with Washington, General Smallwood unpopular amongst the Maryland troops, General Sullivan transferred to Rhode Island. Photostat of Original

ALS, Robert Christie (well known Tory merchant) to his father; tells of moving to New York and awaiting the arrival of a shipload of goods that he expects a good profit from. Tells his father to sell his tobacco for bills of exchange and not to try to export it
ALS, Gen. Anthony Wayne to Polly Wayne; describes a battle with the British that eventually became an American victory. Photostat of Original

ALS, Dr. H. Cooper to George Panton; tells of visit to Panton's parents in the Highlands; sends some money to Panton, asks to be remembered to the members of the Protestant Episcopal Church in America. With Photostat of Original
Note of exchange for fifty-two pounds ten shillings to Major Laurence Parsons, Robert Jackson to James Jackson. Printed Form
ALS, George Lux to Major General Greene; congratulations to Greene on safe retreat from Rhode Island; that will halt the cabal against Greene and Washington. Photostat of Original
ALS, George Washington to [?]; indicates that recipient is in contact with a spy, also Washington tells how short and needed specie is. Photostatic copy
ALS, James Darah to John Ladd Howell; tells of the shortage of salt and action to cope with the problem
ALS, John Jameson to [?]; tells of transporting German prisoners, also of going to Philadelphia to settle his Will and accounts, complaints of British prisoners stealing food etc
AL, [?] to [General Clinton]; British may try to divide and conquer, inaction in the Army and Government is dangerous. Tells of attempts to replace Washington. Photostat of Original
Note of account payable to Benedict Arnold by Dr. Jacob Thompson. Photostat of Original

AL, Horatio Gates to General Thomas Conway; letter will not be forwarded to Conway, General Lee reprimanded by Washington; Dean's accusation of conspiracy between the Lee brothers. Tells Conway to do well at the French. Court. Photographic Copy
Order by Peter Chester, Governor of West Florida, to Elias Durnford, surveyor, to survey 200 acres for William Rogers three miles north of Pensacola
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Col. Jeremiah Wadsworth; chartering of vessels to carry rice from South Carolina not successful; wants to know how to obtain chartered vessels
ALS, Thomas Conway to [?]; forwarding of a letter from Richard Peters, complains of hard work, and doing the best he can. Photograph of Original
ALS, Lieut. Governor N. Bee (South Carolina) to [?]; difficult finding men to man the war gallies; exchange of prisoners discussed with names mentioned
ALS, Jean Clement (Paris) to Horatio Gates; talk of the strength of the French fleet, the possibility of invading England. Photostat of Original

ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; has not received Panton's letter; Panton still has fifteen pounds to draw on, hope that the Rebels will be beaten and legal government restored, so all can join against the French and Spanish. With Photostat of Original

AL, Mr. Law Stillman to Dr. John Morgan (Philadelphia); vindication of Morgan, birth of a daughter to his sister; the death of a boy in town, the forwarding of the sermon preached at the last General Court
AL, Horatio Gates to John Adams inquiring as to who Jean Clement really is
ALS, John Adams to Elbridge Gerry; things in Europe look favorable to America, wants to know who was for and who against his appointment. Photostat of original
ALS, John Buss to Stephen Buss; family talk
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth of Weathersfield; Mrs. Greene had a baby boy; problems with the engineering officers; need of money but none in sight

ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; need of money is desperate; people won't pay taxes, all is disorder, Congress thinking of turning the Army to the States. Congress and the Army are feuding. Blasts against Roger Sherman, urges Wadsworth to run for Congress
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; describing the voyage to England, hopes to obtain Panton's release from prison. With Photostat of Original.
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; food is scarce, no money to pay expenses of express riders, the coming campaign has no field equipage or support

ALS, Nathanael Greene to Mr. Royal Flint; Great Britain will not give up the fight until she loses mastery of the sea. All are divided on the funding policy. The sad state of America and its gloomy prospects leads to fear of trouble at home
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; public affairs are growing worse, fear revolution; Wadsworth should go into politics
Invoice for merchandise for Edward Bancroft consigned to J. Holker, French Consul at Philadelphia
ALS, John Adams to Horatio Gates; introduction of Lafayette's brother, the Viscount de Noailles; asks for information regarding the plan of attack against New York. Photostat of Original
Invoice of merchandise in a trunk shipped to Philadelphia
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; growing feeling of revolution; no money to buy supplies; Charlestown still safe
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; offer of contract for procuring horses for French Army; Charlestown has fallen; British are at Elizabeth Town
ALS, W. Temple to Samuel White; letter had been opened; also no one authorized to draw on Temple's account
Notes of payment of 12 pounds ten shillings to Major General B. Arnold. David Hopkins to Dairel Lenox, Merchant, Philadelphia

ALS, C. Batwell to George Panton; riots in London; colonies will be restored; French squadron is being followed by the British; missionaries will be taken care of in England if the Church falls. With Photostat of Original
ALS, Governor Jonathan Trumbull of Conn. to Treasurer John Lawrence; orders him to press the collection of taxes

ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; 40,000 French are coming; Washington has a plan of attack against New York; feels the states won't furnish necessary men or supplies; gives advice on type of horses to buy
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; French fleet has arrived; if each state fears doing more than its share, little will be accomplished. Roger Sherman is attempting to weaken the army
ALS, Nathaniel Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; letter to the Committee; argument with French representative; need of supplies for New York expedition

ALS, Lord George Germain to Governor Haldriram; Fall of South Carolina; British action in South stopped attempted attacks on Canada, Governor is not to open correspondence directed to the King or one of his officers
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; glad Wadsworth gave up the supplying of the French troops; Greene out of Quarter Masters Corp and glad of it
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; Congress may strip Greene of rank for leaving Quarter Masters job; Sherman is working to hurt Greene
ALS, Horatio Gates to John Hancock; tells of his defeat at Camden

ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; no dismissal of Greene; Army not happy that Timothy Pickering will be taking over Quarter Master's post; we can't supply the second part of the French fleet
ALS, Mr. Batwell to George Panton; capture of some French vessels; loss of most of the British East and West India fleet; Parliament is dissolved; all is electioneering
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; chides Panton for not writing; Peru is in rebellion; tells of movement of British, fleet; fear for Southern army if it's not reinforced. With Photostat of Original
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; announcement of Greene's appointment to command the Southern Army
Notice that Abner Pearce has procured a man to serve in his place, signed J. Winkley, Capt. Commander, 2nd Connecticut Infantry
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; Cornwallis' victory; new Parliament met; record of the King's speech
ALS, T.B. Chandler to. George Panton; asks how to handle Panton's money in England; French should not be allowed to stay at Rhode Island. With Photostat
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; sorrow for Major Andre; relates moves of British land and sea forces; British politics are slowly changing; receipt of a letter from the late Andre. With Photostat
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; handling of Panton's money affairs; Spain was seduced into the war; French are beginning to tire. With Photostat
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; sending a packet of pamphlets. Tells of handling Panton's funds. With Photostat of Original
ALS, H. Cooper to George Panton; possibility of a break with the Dutch; capture of French and American privateers. With photostat of original
ALS, William Clajon to Colonel Hughes at Fishkill; Clajon cleared of charges brought against him by Gates
TLS, Josiah Blakely from William Kenyon; talks of Benedict Arnold and some of his mercantile transactions
ALS, B. Seixas to Aaron Lopez; concerns the loan of money and rate of exchange
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; discusses Panton's investments, outfitting of British privateers against the Dutch. With Photostat
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; reports on Dutch War and looks to the future; problems in the West Indies. Parliament in recess. With Photostat
A coded message from French Ambassador Destouches to [?]; reports the British in Virginia, the inhabitants are trying to save their goods, not fight. Photostat of the original in French
ALS,[N. Greene] to John Adams; tells of the problems encountered in taking up command of the Southern Army. Photostat of Original
ALS, Rochambeau to Washington; tells of destructive gale, hope of having Admiral Destouches' fleet break communication between New York and the South. Photostat of Original
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; talks of stock purchases and bills paid by Chandler for Panton. With Photostat of Original
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; the minority has no chance in this world; national credit high, reinforcements being sent to British garrisons around the world. With Photostat of Original
ALS, M. Destouches to [?]; the French will send vessels and reinforcements into Chesapeake to support. the Americans. Original French letter
ALS, G. Washington to Colonel Dayton; instructing the spies to keep close watch on the British in New York, especially up river, while Lafayette's troops are absent. Photostat of Original

ALS, George Washington to Joseph Jones; if the French sent their whole force to Virginia Arnold's corps would have been destroyed; we should make the most of their assistance without reminding them of their mistakes; need for joint land/sea operations. Photostat of Original
ALS, G. Washington to William Fitzhugh (p. 2&3 only); The army is wasting time and money until the states agree to support it; waiting to hear from Southern army. Photostat of Original
ALS, G. Washington to General Armstrong; complains that the French didn't commit themselves enough around the Chesapeake area. Photostatic copy
Note due, M. Holker at Philadelphia from Luruz Chaumont of Paris. In French
ALS, Theodore Sedgwicke to Jeremiah Wadsworth; introducing Thomas L. Welbuk who is procuring horses for the Frnch Army
ALS, Rochambeau to [Washington]; tells Washington that the French didn't receive his orders in time to send a large fleet to the Chesapeake
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; rumors of the death of Franklin in Paris; New York seems to be cut off from news from England. With Photostatic copy

ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; the British Commanders in Chief don't seem to be doing all they can in America. Cornwallis has not been properly supported. French are not going to send men, ships or money of any consequence this season. With Photostatic copy
ALS, Horatio Gates to Robert Morris; compliments Morris on his taking over the country's finances; Gates to be reviewed for having lost at Camden; fears design to remove him from his command
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; England is quiet, British plan to proceed through Maryland and Pennsylvania; complaint of the poor communication
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; difference between time of letters crossing the Atlantic; British battle plans; rumor of Washington's resignation; sea battles reported. With Photostatic copy
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; England has had no news for a month of impending engagements; condemnation of Monsieur de la Motte for high treason; rumors from America. With Photostatic copy
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; England restless over the lack of action in America; description of some of England's land battles. With Photostatic copy
ALS, P. Cortland to [?]; describes the events leading to Cornwallis' surrender. Photostatic copy
AL, Henry Knox to John Adams; description of the fall and surrender of Yorktown; praise for Greene; good harmony between French and American troops. Draft of letter; Photostatic copy
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; Chandler was sick; the investment of Panton's money; comments on the capture of Lord Cornwallis and the death of martyrs for England. With photostatic copy
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; tries to console Panton on the British losses, but fears for lack of British action. With Photostatic copy
ALS, William Duer to Leonard Gansevoort at Albany; talks of trade and merchandise, also of Robert Morris's plan to dissolve the various boards set up by Congress
Synopsis of the Campaign, 1781, as an aid to understanding the map. Photostat of Original. Written in French with English typed copy
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; Britain will not give up America; Br. will field army; Loyalists shouldn't lose hope. With Photostatic Copy
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; the removal of Germain from office; no American Secretary; peace with the Dutch is in suspense; provision for the American clergy. With photostat of Original

ALS, Nathanael Greene to [?]; where is revenue to come from but the states? If we don't help ourselves, we can't expect it from others; prices and transportation complaint; tells of how difficult provisions are to come by
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; Sir Guy Carlton appointed to Chief Command in America; attempt at defensive war in America. With Photostatic copy
ALS, Johann Christian Gerning (a noted Danish entomologist) to his patron; speaks of his health, publications and his entomological work
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; new ministry, speaks of how the new ministry and administration will affect England. With Photostat of Original
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; change in ministry; New York not in immediate danger. Procrastination has deeply ruined English chance of success. With Photostat of Original
George Panton to Thomas Bradbury Chandler [?], London, England
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; introduction of Rev. Mr. Moore. Batwell is despondent over the fate of America. With Photostat of Oriainal
ALS, George Clinton to Colonel Philip van Renssalaer; monetary matters
ALS, G. Washington to John Hancock; the number and disposition of British troops at Halifax requested
ALS, D. Batwell to George Panton; Britain trying to cut French aid; sarcastic letter about the change of command. With Photostat of Original
TLS, George Washington to Colonel Olney regarding Ensign Johnson whom Washington has never heard of
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; Russia is to join England with 15 sail of the line, because the Dutch won't make peace with England. With Photostat of Original
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; concerns Panton's investments and salary due from the Missionary Society. With Photostat Of Original
Exchange note to Joshua Loring from Henry Knox carried by General Lincoln, worth $500
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; writes of financial affairs and of the relief convoy to Gibraltar and the damage caused by gale and accident to the ships. With Photostat of Oriainal

ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton;Colonies are being given away by the commissioners in Paris; Governor of New York has not yet handed over the address by Loyalist to the King. With Photostat of Original
ALS, Matthew Ridley to (?); from Paris with a discussion of Peace
ALS, Gen. Christie to (Allea?) Adam in London; monetary matters; charge of traitor lodged against Christie; also his son mentioned in the newspapers

ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; state of Panton's finances; prices will fall unless there is a general peace; negotiations at Paris renewed; only Britain has stopped the rebellion from falling apart by internal decay. With Photostat of Original
ALS, Peter R. Livingston to Jeremiah Wadsworth; purchase of flour at a commission. Photostat of Original

ALS, Matthew Ridley to Governor Morris; if there is no peace so the combined French and Spanish fleets are prepared to fight vigorously both in the United States and in the East Indies, America must be a friend of all, but independent of all
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; no stock purchase price too high due to rumor of peace; rumor of peace treaty arrives. With Photostat of Original
ALS, Jonathan Williams (B. Franklin's Secretary in France) to Mr. White; "All goes right where my person is, but the Devil gets into everything when my back is turned."
Note for receipt of $5 from Timothy Pickering to Abram Slutt; Marvel Slutt; Francis Weldon for carting provisions
ALS, T.B. Chandler to George Panton; stocks are rising; preliminary peace signed with France and Spain. With Photostat of Original
Receipt for $9 and 17/19 for carting wood. From Timothy Pickering, Quarter Master General, to Abraham Strickbud
ALS, Matthew Ridley to Governor Morris; from Paris, final peace has not yet been signed; England is split by parties and factions; problem of refugees;people in America must pay taxes
ALS, Mendosa and Brush (merchants) from Mederia to Howe and Colt (merchants), New Haven; open trade exchanging American produce for wine, need for horses. With list of articles and exchange notes
ALS, Thomas Sharpe to Samuel Ridout; concerns reading books; family discussion, difficult to read
ALS, George Ross to Robert Morris, asking Morris to represent him
ALS, G.[underline]P.[underline] to John Uardherded, Esq.; talks of heads and punishment, seems to fear capital punishment for crimes committed at New York. With Photostat of Same
ALS, Lord North (Duke of Portland?); asks to admit General Vaughan to the Order of Bath; North had attack of gout
ALS, William Livingston to General David Foreman; asks him to find some one to rescue a departed loyalist's --Sir Charles Douglas-- property
ALS, George III, King of England; General Order concerning the buying and selling of commissions by second officers
ALS, William Gordon (Famous historian of the American Revolution) to (?), concerns the purchase of books
ALS, Peter Livingston to (Aaron Burr?); wants recipient to look into Court Records for a bill due, also to pay for sugar sent. Photostat of Original
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; Greene in financial difficulties; asks Wadsworth to back his note; asks Wadsworth to buy into Cumberland Island; talks of going into the Spanish trade
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; concerns the purchase of Cumberland Island
ALS, Charles Thomson to John Lawrence; concerning the question of whether the Court of Appeals still exists
Nathanael Greene appointing Jeremiah Wadsworth as true and lawful attorney to sign and dispose of lands. Legal form
ALS, Nathanael Greene to [Marboro]; a description of Cumberland Island and reason for selling part of it
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; Greene doesn't want to sell more than one quarter of the island if he can get clear of his creditors
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; note drawn on Wadsworth for $300 by Greene to pay John Kean
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; trying to sell a vessel to get money; will so journey north
ALS, Marquis de Lafayette to [?]; concerns the Society of the Cincinnatus. Photostatic Copy
ALS, William Livingston to Messers Arnold and Halsey; there is no Attachment Law at present in New York; it is impossible to attach Silvester Fuller's property
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; concerns monetary matters and Nathanael's brother, Griffin; Mrs. Greene is not well
Indenture between Robert and Hannah Harris, and John DeLancey and Robert Morris; of land owned by Harris but given over for one year to DeLancey and Morris for one peppercorn
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; loss of a child, wife and daughter ill; going to send a ship to carry tobacco from Virginia; financial affairs better
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; need of a tutor to replace the one who just resigned
ALS, Samuel Adams to [J. Adams]; fear of the Society of Cincinnatus
Notice to all: Nathanael Greene for {symble}960-3-4 sold his interest in the Barnabas Dean & Co. stock to Jeremiah Wadsworth
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; has found a tutor, a Mr. Miller of New Haven, and cancel previous request
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; sending deed for his North River property for Wadsworth to sell; hopes to be able to pay debts with the profit from his crop
ALS, Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; Wadsworth's son and Mr. Miller arrived at the same time to be tutors; Greene finally decides on Miller
Nathanael Greene appoints Jeremiah Wadsworth his true, sufficient and lawful attorney. Notice: Legal Document
ALS, Augustus N. (?) to Mr. Clark; sign enclosed note. Saved for watermark by Knollenberg
Retainer for Alexander Hamilton from the holders of the Spitzburg Patent holders
ALS, Robert Morris to John Nicholson (comptroller of Penn.) refusing to get involved in a dispute between U.S. and Pennsylvania

A letter to the Governor and Council of Maryland from Robert Smith to find out if it is legal to pay the interest on a purchased piece of property in certificate money or if only specie will be received
ALS, William Burnet; Randal Hayes; Daniel Marsh to Mrs. Mary Ashfield; Mrs. Ashfield defrauded on a land deal
ALS, Pierce Butler to Thomas Fitzsimons (merchant in Philadelphia); Butler has been defrauded in Holland; asks Fitzsimons to do him a favor
A List of debts claimed in Pennsylvania against Benedict Arnold at the time of his treason.{symbol}398.2
Amount of the sales of the estates of Benedict Arnold forfeited to the State of Pennsylvania. {symbol}1547. 14. 9
ALS, Alexander Hamilton to Robert Morris; approval of Declaration
ALS, Robert Morris to William Constable; invitation to stop in and asks him to mail some letters for France
ALS, James Hillhouse to Dudley Woodbridge; a demand against Woodbridge was presented that was greater than his account
ALS, Robert Morris to Mrs. Robert Morris; thanking for information obtained
ALS, Joel Barlow to Abraham Baldwin; pick up balance owed Barlow by Ohio Company
Receipt signed by William Tapp, Treasurer of the Ohio Co. for $9,848 40/90 from Joel Barlow
List of certificates paid by Abiel Griswold in part of his share in the Ohio Co
List of certificates paid by Abjah Cotton for one share in the Ohio Co
List of certificates paid by John Watson for one share in the Ohio Co
List of certificates paid by Nathan Whiting in part of his one share in the Ohio Co
List of certificates paid to Samuel Wright in full for his share in the Ohio Co
List of proprietors of Ohio Co. for whose shares Joel Barlow is accountable
List of notes ent the treasurer of the Ohio Co. by Joel Barlow
List of soldiers whose rights Joel Barlow has purchased
ALS, Charles Thomson to the President of Congress explaining the 5th Article of Confederation
ALS, James Gardoqui to George Washington; present of the latest Spanish edition of Don Quixote to the General
Quit-Claim for $100 of 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. from Daniel Curtis to Joel Barlow
ALS, Thomas Lord to Joel Barlow giving him power of attorney for 10 soldiers dealing with the Ohio Co
Quit-Claim for $100 for 1/10 of I share of and in the Ohio Co. From Jesse Taylor to Joel Barlow
ALS, Josiah Starr to Joel Barlow; concerns the Ohio Association and who owns what
Mayor's Court New York, complaint of Cory Ludlow against John Leary for debt
Quit-Claim for $100 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Jeduthun Abby to Joel Barlow
Quit-Claim for $100 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Levi Risely to Joel Barlow
Quit-Claim for $100 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. John Lerou to Joel Barlow
ALS, Admiral Auguste De Grasse to George Washington; Photostat
Quit-Claim for $100 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Israel Rowley to Joel Barlow
Quit-Claim for $100 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Moses; Griswold to Joel Barlow
Quit-claim for $100 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Thomas Wells to Joel Barlow
Quit-claim for $200 for 1/5 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Thomas Anderson to Joel Barlow
Account book of Joel Barlow as agent for the Ohio Land Co
Quit-claim for $100 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Giles Wilcox to Joel Barlow
Quit-claim for for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. William Wease to Joel Barlow
Quit-claim for for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Charles Reynolds to Joel Barlow
Quit-claim for $3 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Matthew Ford to Joel Barlow
Memorandum receipt of $950 from Mr. Wallam for I share of Ohio Co. stock
Quit-claim for $3 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. John Reynolds to Joel Barlow
Quit-claim for 20 shillings for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Peleg Heath to Joel Barlow
Quit-claim for $3 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Jesse Harwood to Joel Barlow
Quit-claim for $3 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Allen Corning to Joel Barlow
Quit-claim for $100 for l/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Uriah Mead to Aaron Barlow
Quit-claim for $100 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Solomon Williams to Aaron Barlow
Map of Township No. 6 in Range 15. In Ohio Co.?
ALS, Samuel Parker (Minister Trinity Church, Later PEC Bishop of Massachusetts) to Ebenezer Corey; pay to John Palmer 5-8-31
ALS, Theodore Sedgwick to Alexander Hodgdon; has to get to Congress to ask for a 50 or 60 pound loan
ALS, Mrs. Nathanael Greene to Jeremiah Wadsworth; things going well; asks Wadsworth to come down
Quit-claim for $100 for 1/10 of 1 share of land in the Ohio Co. Luke Roberts to Aaron Barlow. Notice of receipt of money signed John Jay from R Robert Morris
Notice of receipt of money signed John Jay from Robert Morris
ALS, William Lee to Robert Carter inquring whether his vessel is to go to Baltimore
Circular from Treasury Department: how to determine tonnage of vessels - Alexander Hamilton
ADS, Steubening; Record of money paid and owed (French)
Receipt of two bonds from Janet Probasco for {symble} 196.1.1 and {symble} 27.16.3 Frederick Frelinghuysen
Pay to the order of Benjamin Clinch {symble}15 signed Peter Gansvoort
ALS, George Washington to Beverly Randolph; thank you for. information concerning the Western country. Photostat of Original
ALS, (Draft) Samuel Huntington to Oliver Ellsworth; Jonathan Trumbull and other notifying them of their election to Congress
ALS, Stephen Higginson to Messers. Le Roy and Bayard; congratulating them at forming a new firm. Most of letter deals with business transactions pending
ALS, Philip Schuyler to (?); drinking wine despite orders not to; complains of the hot weather
ALS, General Knox to Samuel Hodgdon (Quarter Master) troops should move into the Ohio
ALS, William Duer to Benjamin Walker, procurement of supplies for troops
ALS, Christopher P. Yates (able lawyer; member of Congress) to Abraham Hun; need to post notice of a matter referred to in previous letter
ALS, Christopher Gore (Governor of Massachusetts) to Samuel Russell Gerry (Collector of Port Marble head); Gerry must enforce the laws of the U.S
Envelope addressed to Robert Morris by Alexander Hamilton
Memorandum by Henry Lee of a transfer to W.A. Washington of ... a judgement ... against Peter Conway
Notice to Sheriff of Queens County of N.Y. to take James Smith, signed by Mr. Nesson
ALS, General Knox to Samuel Hodgdon; order to supply clothes to the troops of a Lt. Thompson
ALS, General Knox to Samuel Hodgdon; to provide clothing for the 95 men under Lt. Richards
AL, Alexander Hamilton to John Ball; instructions on bow to pay $400,000 loan
ALS, Edward Livingston to (?) enclosing a list of bonds left in the hands of Matthew(?) Visscher; plus discussion of various legal matters
ALS, General Henry Knox to General Jackson urging "no war by the Grace of God"
ALS, Daniel Howell (Member of Congress) to (?); concerns the case of Benjamin Weeden to the court of common pleas
Envelope signed Edward Randolph to (Robert) Morris
ALS, Theodore Sedgwick to Justin Ely; concerns Congressional elections in Massachusetts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains letters, diaries, addresses, papers and a printed book. The material is listed by author's name, and is arranged chronologically.

Included are two volumes of papers and letters by Francois Alexandre-Frederick La Rochefoucauld Liancourt, writings of Seth Reynolds, a book on the Civil War by Theodore F. Vail and diaries of Alfred Brammer, English workman.
See Also: Series I for correspondence of Seth Reynolds.
